Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Influence of Low-Carbon Energy Technology Scientists and Engineers on the Composition of Energy Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This project is a collaborative, multi-sited ethnographic study that will examine how the rhetoric used by scientists serves to influence scientific contributions to policy.

Intellectual Merit

The researchers will examine how scientists engage and argue with one another about policy. Specifically, they will collect and analyze the rhetoric used by scientists who are engaged in the development of two types of low carbon energy technologies, wind power and nuclear power, in order to understand how the composition of their reasoning influences energy policy, and how their rhetoric could serve as a productive starting point for integrating scientific knowledge into policy decisions.

Broader Impacts

The project has societal relevance in terms of training a diverse set of students in social science methodologies and of making the participating scientists aware of the results so as to improve the integration of science in policymaking with respect to the crucial issues of climate change mitigation and energy security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy systems are undergoing fundamental changes, due partially to a nexus created by new technologies combined with increased social expectations for those systems. This project produced publications that clarify the reasoning of scientists and engineers involved in this energy change, suggest ways they seek to influence this system change, and explore possible opportunities for the general public to become more involved at every level.  It also trained new professionals who will be leaders in various aspect of these changes.

Outcomes of this project include several peer-reviewed publications and conference papers, as well as a Masters thesis; all listed in the final report.   The project also provided the impetus for a symposium on energy democracy held at the University of Utah. My co-PI, two other colleagues, and I then worked with participants, as well as issuing an open call for additional papers, to publish a special issue of Frontiers in Communication (https://www.frontiersin.org/research-topics/6005/energy-democracy).  That endeavor led to an invitation (from Routledge) to edit a handbook on the topic, which is currently in process.

While these are important outcomes, the most exciting outcomes relate to professional development for students and the post-doctoral researcher. University of Texas at El Paso more than matched the funds that came from a small REU supplement granted by NSF. I also was able to leverage startup funds to cover additional student and post-doctoral research support.  Developing a small cohort seemed especially important, given that most of our students come from backgrounds that do not emphasize formal education.

None of the undergraduate students whose involvement was made possible by the REU supplement had previously considered research and graduate work. Although not all of them became involved in further research, some did. One student began working as an undergraduate research assistant, then transitioned to working as a graduate research assistant (using funds made available by University of Texas at El Paso). He based his MA thesis on the project, and has now moved to a PhD program at the University of Utah, where he received a highly competitive fellowship.  The person who worked as a post-doctoral researcher on the project developed exceptional skills in using NVivo qualitative data management software; and has moved into a tenure-track position at a small university.  She now is utilizing project management skills that she developed while working on this project. In addition to the MA student mentioned above, three other undergraduate research assistants decided to pursue graduate degrees, one in communication, and two in natural sciences. The communication student is currently a MA student at another university, and one of those interested in natural sciences is currently a MS student in ecology at another university. The third is a senior at UTEP. After working on the project, she became a double major in biology and communication, which means she will not graduate until May 2020.  In the meantime, she was able to use the research skills she gained on this project to secure a summer internship with the Polaris Project (funded by NSF since 2008). I am continuing to mentor her, as she looks toward future graduate work.
